column1: The Dyatlov Pass incident (Russian: Гибель тургруппы Дятлова) was an event in which nine Russian hikers died in the northern Ural Mountains between 1 and 2 February 1959
column2: in uncertain circumstances. The experienced trekking group
column3: who were all from the Ural Polytechnical Institute
column4: had established a camp on the slopes of Kholat Syakhl
column5: in an area now named in honour of the group's leader
column6: Igor Dyatlov. During the night
column7: something caused them to tear their way out of their tents and flee the campsite while inadequately dressed for the heavy snowfall and subzero temperatures.

column1: After the group's bodies were discovered
column2: an investigation by Soviet authorities determined that six had died from hypothermia while the other three showed signs of physical trauma. One victim had a fractured skull; two others had major chest fractures
column3: one body was missing both its eyes
column4: and one was missing a tongue. The investigation concluded that a "compelling natural force" had caused the deaths. Numerous theories have been put forward to account for the unexplained deaths
column5: including animal attacks
column6: hypothermia
column7: avalanche

column1: Russia opened a new investigation into the incident in 2019
column2: and its conclusions were presented in July 2020: that the cause of death was hypothermia due to a combination of an avalanche
column3: forcing the group to leave their camp
column4: combined with low visibility. Andrey Kuryakov
column5: deputy head of the regional prosecutor's office
column6: said: “It was a heroic struggle. There was no panic. But they had no chance to save themselves under the circumstances.”

column2: a group was formed for a skiing expedition across the northern Urals in Sverdlovsk Oblast
column3: Soviet Union. According to Prosecutor Tempalov
column4: documents that were found in the tent of the expedition suggest that the expedition was named for the 21st Congress of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union
column5: and was possibly dispatched by the local Komsomol organisation. Igor Dyatlov
column6: a 23-year-old radio engineering student at the Ural Polytechnical Institute (Уральский политехнический институт
column7: УПИ; now Ural Federal University) was the leader who assembled a group of nine others for the trip
column8: most of whom were fellow students and peers at the university. Each member of the group
column9: which consisted of eight men and two women
column10: was an experienced Grade II-hiker with ski tour experience
column11: and would be receiving Grade III certification upon their return. At the time
column12: this was the highest certification available in the Soviet Union
column13: and required candidates to traverse 300 kilometres (190 mi). The route was designed by Dyatlov's group to reach the far northern regions of Sverdlovsk Oblast and the upper-streams of the Lozva river. The route was approved by the Sverdlovsk city route commission. This was a division of the Sverdlovsk Committee of Physical Culture and Sport and they confirmed the group of 10 people on January 8th
column14: 1959. The goal of the expedition was to reach Gora Otorten (Гора Отортен)
column15: a mountain 10 kilometres (6.2 mi) north of the site where the incident occurred. This route undertaken in February was estimated as a Category III
column16: the most difficult time to traverse.

column1: On 23 January 1959 the Dyatlov group was issued their route book which listed their course as following the No.5 trail. At that time
column2: the Sverdlovsk City Committee of Physical Culture and Sport listed approval for 11 people. The 11th person was listed as Semyon Zolotaryov who was previously certified to go with another expedition of similar difficulty (the Sogrin expedition group). The Dyatlov group left the Sverdlovsk city (today Yekaterinburg) on the same day they received the route book.

column1: The group arrived by train at Ivdel (Ивдель)
column2: a town at the centre of the northern province of Sverdlovsk Oblast in the early morning hours of January 25
column3: 1959. They then took a truck to Vizhai (Вижай)
column4: a lorry village that is the last inhabited settlement to the north. While spending the night in Vizhai
column5: the skiers purchased and ate loaves of bread to keep their energy levels up for the following day's hike.On January 27
column6: they began their trek toward Gora Otorten. On January 28
column7: one member
column9: who suffered from several health ailments (including rheumatism and a congenital heart defect) turned back due to knee and joint pain that made him unable to continue the hike. The remaining nine hikers continued the trek.

column1: Diaries and cameras found around their last campsite made it possible to track the group's route up to the day preceding the incident. On 31 January
column2: the group arrived at the edge of a highland area and began to prepare for climbing. In a wooded valley
column3: they cached surplus food and equipment that would be used for the trip back. The next day
column4: the hikers started to move through the pass. It seems they planned to get over the pass and make camp for the next night on the opposite side
column5: but because of worsening weather conditions—snowstorms and decreasing visibility—they lost their direction and deviated west
column6: toward the top of Kholat Syakhl. When they realised their mistake
column7: the group decided to set up camp there on the slope of the mountain
column8: rather than move 1.5 kilometres (0.93 mi) downhill to a forested area that would have offered some shelter from the weather. Yudin speculated
column9: "Dyatlov probably did not want to lose the altitude they had gained
column10: or he decided to practice camping on the mountain slope."

column2: Dyatlov had agreed he would send a telegram to their sports club as soon as the group returned to Vizhai. It was expected that this would happen no later than 12 February
column3: but Dyatlov had told Yudin
column4: before he departed from the group
column5: that he expected it to be longer. When the 12th passed and no messages had been received
column6: there was no immediate reaction
column7: as delays of a few days were common with such expeditions. On 20 February
column8: the travellers' relatives demanded a rescue operation and the head of the institute sent the first rescue groups
column9: consisting of volunteer students and teachers. Later
column10: the army and militsiya forces became involved
column11: with planes and helicopters ordered to join the operation.

column2: the searchers found the group's abandoned and badly damaged tent on Kholat Syakhl. The campsite baffled the search party. Mikhail Sharavin
column3: the student who found the tent
column4: said "the tent was half torn down and covered with snow. It was empty
column5: and all the group's belongings and shoes had been left behind." Investigators said the tent had been cut open from inside. Nine sets of footprints
column6: left by people wearing only socks or a single shoe or even barefoot
column7: could be followed
column8: leading down to the edge of a nearby woods
column9: on the opposite side of the pass
column10: 1.5 kilometres (0.93 mi) to the north-east. After 500 metres (1
column11: 600 ft) these tracks were covered with snow. At the forest's edge
column13: the searchers found the visible remains of a small fire. There were the first two bodies
column15: shoeless and dressed only in underwear. The branches on the tree were broken up to five meters high
column16: suggesting that one of the skiers had climbed up to look for something
column17: perhaps the camp. Between the pine and the camp
column18: the searchers found three more corpses: Dyatlov
column21: who died in poses suggesting that they were attempting to return to the tent. They were found at distances of 300

column1: Finding the remaining four travellers took more than two months. They were finally found on 4 May under four metres (13 ft) of snow in a ravine 75 metres (246 ft) further into the woods from the pine tree. Three of the four were better dressed than the others
column2: and there were signs that those who had died first had their clothes relinquished to the others. Dubinina was wearing Krivonishenko's burned
column3: torn trousers and her left foot and shin were wrapped in a torn jacket.

column1: A legal inquest started immediately after the first five bodies were found. A medical examination found no injuries that might have led to their deaths
column2: and it was concluded that they had all died of hypothermia. Slobodin had a small crack in his skull
column3: but it was not thought to be a fatal wound.An examination of the four bodies found in May shifted the narrative of the incident. Three of the hikers had fatal injuries: Thibeaux-Brignolles had major skull damage
column4: and Dubinina and Zolotaryov had major chest fractures. According to Boris Vozrozhdenny
column5: the force required to cause such damage would have been extremely high
column6: comparable to that of a car crash. Notably
column7: the bodies had no external wounds associated with the bone fractures
column8: as if they had been subjected to a high level of pressure.All four bodies found at the bottom of the creek in a running stream of water had soft tissue damage to their head and face. For example
column12: as well as facial tissue and a fragment of skullbone
column13: while Zolotaryov had his eyeballs missing
column14: and Aleksander Kolevatov his eyebrows. V. A. Vozrozhdenny
column15: the forensic expert performing the post-mortem examination
column16: judged that these injuries happened post-mortem due to the location of the bodies in a stream.

column1: There was initial speculation that the indigenous Mansi people
column2: reindeer herders local to the area
column3: had attacked and murdered the group for encroaching upon their lands. Several Mansi were interrogated
column4: but the investigation indicated that the nature of the deaths did not support this hypothesis: only the hikers' footprints were visible
column5: and they showed no sign of hand-to-hand struggle.Although the temperature was very low
column6: around −25 to −30 °C (−13 to −22 °F) with a storm blowing
column7: the dead were only partially dressed. Some had only one shoe
column8: while others wore only socks. Some were found wrapped in snips of ripped clothes that seemed to have been cut from those who were already dead.

column1: Journalists reporting on the available parts of the inquest files claim that it states:
Six of the group members died of hypothermia and three of fatal injuries.
There were no indications of other people nearby on Kholat Syakhl apart from the nine travellers.
The tent had been ripped open from within.
The victims had died six to eight hours after their last meal.
Traces from the camp showed that all group members left the campsite of their own accord
column2: on foot.

column1: High levels of radiation were found on only one victim's clothing.
To dispel the theory of an attack by the indigenous Mansi people
column2: Vozrozhdenny stated that the fatal injuries of the three bodies could not have been caused by human beings
column3: "because the force of the blows had been too strong and no soft tissue had been damaged".

column1: Released documents contained no information about the condition of the skiers' internal organs.

There were no survivors.At the time the verdict was that the group members had died because of a compelling natural force. The inquest officially ceased in May 1959 as a result of the absence of a guilty party. The files were sent to a secret archive.In 1997
column2: it was revealed that the negatives from Krivonischenko's camera were kept in the private archive of one of the investigators
column3: Lev Ivanov. The film material was donated by Ivanov's daughter to the Dyatlov Foundation. The diaries of the hiking party fell into Russia's public domain in 2009.

column2: Zolotarev's remains were exhumed on the initiative of journalists of the Russian tabloid newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda. Contradictory results were obtained: one of the experts said that the character of the injuries resembled a person knocked down by a car
column3: and the DNA analysis did not reveal any similarity to the DNA of living relatives. In addition
column4: it turned out that Zolotarev's name was not on the list of those buried at the Ivanovskoye cemetery. Nevertheless
column5: the reconstruction of the face from the exhumed skull matched postwar photographs of Zolotarev
column6: although journalists expressed suspicions that another person was hiding under Zolotarev's name after World War II.In February 2019
column7: Russian authorities reopened the investigation into the incident
column8: although only three possible explanations were being considered: an avalanche
column10: or a hurricane. The possibility of a crime has been discounted.

column2: who later became the head of the Yekaterinburg-based Dyatlov Foundation
column3: attended five of the hikers' funerals. He recalled that their skin had a "deep brown tan".

column1: Another group of hikers (about 50 kilometres (31 mi) south of the incident) reported that they saw strange orange spheres in the sky to the north on the night of the incident. Similar spheres were observed in Ivdel and adjacent areas continually during the period from February to March 1959
column2: by various independent witnesses (including the meteorology service and the military). These sightings were not noted in the 1959 investigation
column3: and the various witnesses came forward years later.

column1: Anatoly Gushchin (Russian: Анатолий Гущин) summarized his research in the book The Price of State Secrets Is Nine Lives (Цена гостайны – девять жизней
column2: Sverdlovsk
column3: 1990) Some researchers criticised the work for its concentration on the speculative theory of a Soviet secret weapon experiment
column4: but its publication led to public discussion
column5: stimulated by interest in the paranormal. Indeed
column6: many of those who had remained silent for thirty years reported new facts about the accident. One of them was the former police officer
column7: Lev Ivanov (Лев Иванов)
column8: who led the official inquest in 1959. In 1990
column9: he published an article that included his admission that the investigation team had no rational explanation for the incident. He also stated that
column10: after his team reported that they had seen flying spheres
column11: he then received direct orders from high-ranking regional officials to dismiss this claim.In 2000
column12: a regional television company produced the documentary film The Mystery of Dyatlov Pass (Тайна перевала Дятлова). With the help of the film crew
column15: published a docudrama novella of the same name. A large part of the book includes broad quotations from the official case
column17: interviews with searchers and other documentaries collected by the film-makers. The narrative line of the book details the everyday life and thoughts of a modern woman (an alter ego of the author herself) who attempts to resolve the case. Despite its fictional narrative
column18: Matveyeva's book remains the largest source of documentary materials ever made available to the public regarding the incident. Also
column19: the pages of the case files and other documentaries (in photocopies and transcripts) are gradually being published on a web forum for enthusiastic researchers.The Dyatlov Foundation was founded in 1999 at Yekaterinburg
column20: with the help of Ural State Technical University
column21: led by Yuri Kuntsevitch (Юрий Кунцевич). The foundation's stated aim is to continue investigation of the case and to maintain the Dyatlov Museum to preserve the memory of the dead hikers. On 1 July 2016
column22: a memorial plaque was inaugurated in Solikamsk in Ural's Perm Region
column23: dedicated to Yuri Yudin (the sole survivor of the expedition group)

column2: Andrey Kuryakov
column3: deputy head of the Urals Federal District directorate of the Prosecutor-General’s Office
column4: announced an avalanche to be the "official cause of death" for the Dyatlov group in 1959.

column2: American skeptic author Benjamin Radford suggests an avalanche as more plausible:

column1: that the group woke up in a panic (...) and cut their way out the tent either because an avalanche had covered the entrance to their tent or because they were scared that an avalanche was imminent (...) (better to have a potentially repairable slit in a tent than risk being buried alive in it under tons of snow). They were poorly clothed because they had been sleeping
column2: and ran to the safety of the nearby woods where trees would help slow oncoming snow. In the darkness of night
column3: they got separated into two or three groups; one group made a fire (hence the burned hands) while the others tried to return to the tent to recover their clothing since the danger had passed. But it was too cold
column4: and they all froze to death before they could locate their tent in the darkness. At some point
column5: some of the clothes may have been recovered or swapped from the dead
column6: but at any rate
column7: the group of four whose bodies was most severely damaged were caught in an avalanche and buried under 4 meters (13 ft) of snow (more than enough to account for the 'compelling natural force' the medical examiner described). Dubinina's tongue was likely removed by scavengers and ordinary predation.Evidence contradicting the avalanche theory includes:The location of the incident did not have any obvious signs of an avalanche having taken place. An avalanche would have left certain patterns and debris distributed over a wide area. The bodies found within a month of the event were covered with a very shallow layer of snow and
column8: had there been an avalanche of sufficient strength to sweep away the second party
column9: these bodies would have been swept away as well; this would have caused more serious and different injuries in the process and would have damaged the tree line.

column1: Over 100 expeditions to the region were held since the incident
column2: and none of them ever reported conditions that might create an avalanche. A study of the area using up-to-date terrain-related physics revealed that the location was entirely unlikely for such an avalanche to have occurred. The "dangerous conditions" found in another nearby area (which had significantly steeper slopes and cornices) were observed in April and May when the snowfalls of winter were melting. During February
column3: when the incident occurred
column4: there were no such conditions.

column1: An analysis of the terrain and the slope shows that even if there could have been a very specific avalanche that found its way around
column2: its path would have gone past the tent. It had collapsed from the side but not in a horizontal direction.

column1: Dyatlov was an experienced skier and the much older Zolotaryov was studying for his Masters Certificate in ski instruction and mountain hiking. Neither of these two men would have been likely to camp anywhere in the path of a potential avalanche.
Footprint patterns leading away from the tent were inconsistent with someone
column2: let alone a group of 9 people
column3: running in panic from either real or imagined danger. All the footprints leading away from the tent and towards the woods were consistent with individuals who were walking at a normal pace.

column1: A review of the 1959 investigation's evidence completed in 2015–2019 by experienced investigators from the Investigative Committee of the Russian Federation (ICRF) on request of the families confirmed the avalanche with several important details added. First of all
column2: the ICRF investigators (one of them an experienced alpinist) confirmed that the weather on the night of the tragedy was very harsh
column3: with wind speeds up to hurricane force
column4: 20–30 metres per second (45–67 mph)
column5: a snowstorm and temperatures reaching −40 °C. These factors weren't considered by the 1959 investigators who arrived at the scene of the accident three weeks later when the weather had much improved and any remains of the snow slide settled down and had been covered with fresh snowfall. The harsh weather at the same time played a critical role in the events of the tragic night
column6: which has been reconstructed as follows:

column1: On 1 February the group arrives at the Kholat Syakhl mountain and erects a large
column2: 9-person tent on an open slope
column3: without any natural barriers
column4: such as forests. On the day and a few preceding days
column5: a heavy snowfall continued
column6: with strong wind and frost.

column2: traversing through the slope and digging in the tent into the snow weakens the snow base. During the night the snowfield above the tent starts to slide down slowly under the weight of the new snow
column3: gradually pushing on the tent fabric
column4: starting from the entrance. The group wakes up and starts evacuation in panic
column5: with only some able to put on warm clothes. Since the entrance was blocked
column6: the group escapes through a hole cut in the tent fabric and descends the slope to find a place perceived as safe from the avalanche only 1500 m down
column7: at the forest border.

column1: Due to some of the members having very incomplete clothes
column2: the group splits. Two of the group
column3: only in their underwear and pajamas
column4: were found at the Siberian pine tree
column5: near a fire pit. Their bodies were found first and confirmed to have died from hypothermia.

column2: including Dyatlov
column3: attempted to climb back to the tent

column5: but still quite light and their footwear was incomplete. Their bodies were found at various places ranging 300–600 m from the campfire
column6: in poses suggesting they fell of exhaustion while trying to climb in deep snow in extremely cold weather.

column2: equipped with warm clothes and footwear
column3: were trying to find or build a better camping place in the forest further down the slope. Their bodies were found 70 m from the fireplace

column5: the factors contributing to the tragedy were extremely bad weather and lack of experience of the group leader in such conditions
column6: which led to the selection of a dangerous camping place. After the snow slide
column7: another mistake of the group was to split up
column8: rather than building a temporary camping place down in the forest and trying to survive through the night. Negligence of the 1959 investigators contributed to their report creating more questions than answers and inspiring numerous conspiracy theories.

column2: a Swedish-Russian expedition was made to the site
column3: and after investigations
column4: they proposed that a violent katabatic wind is a likely explanation for the incident. Katabatic winds are somewhat rare events
column5: and can be extremely violent. They were implicated in a 1978 case at Anaris Mountain in Sweden
column6: where eight hikers were killed and one was seriously injured in the aftermath of katabatic wind. The topography of these locations were noted to be very similar according to the expedition.A sudden katabatic wind would have made it impossible to remain in the tent
column7: and the most rational course of action would be for the hikers to cover the tent with snow and seek shelter among the treeline. There was also a torch left turned on on top of the tent
column8: possibly left there intentionally so the hikers could find their way back to the tent once the winds subsided. The expedition proposed that the group of hikers constructed two bivouac shelters
column10: leaving four of the hikers buried with the violent injuries observed.

column1: Another hypothesis popularised by Donnie Eichar's 2013 book Dead Mountain is that wind going around Kholat Syakal created a Kármán vortex street
column2: which can produce infrasound capable of inducing panic attacks in humans.
the infrasound generated by the wind as it passed over the top of the Holatchahl mountain was responsible for causing physical discomfort and mental distress in the hikers. Eichar claims that
column3: because of their panic
column4: the hikers were driven to leave the tent by whatever means necessary
column5: and fled down the slope. By the time they were further down the hill
column6: they would have been out of the infrasound's path and would have regained their composure
column7: but in the darkness would be unable to return to their shelter. The traumatic injuries suffered by three of the victims were the result of their stumbling over the ledge of a ravine in the darkness and landing on the rocks at the bottom.

column1: Speculation exists that the campsite fell within the path of a Soviet parachute mine exercise. This theory alleges that the hikers
column2: woken by loud explosions
column3: fled the tent in a shoeless panic and found themselves unable to return for supply retrieval. After some members froze to death attempting to endure the bombardment
column4: others commandeered their clothing only to be fatally injured by subsequent parachute mine concussions. There are indeed records of parachute mines being tested by the Soviet military in the area around the time the hikers were there. Parachute mines detonate while still in the air rather than upon striking the Earth's surface and produce signature injuries similar to those experienced by the hikers: heavy internal damage with comparably less external trauma. The theory coincides with reported sightings of glowing
column5: orange orbs floating or falling in the sky within the general vicinity of the hikers and allegedly photographed by them
column6: potentially military aircraft or descending parachute mines. This theory (among others) uses scavenging animals to explain Dubinina's injuries. Some speculate the bodies were unnaturally manipulated due to characteristic livor mortis markings discovered during an autopsy
column7: as well as burns to hair and skin. Photographs of the tent allegedly show that it was erected incorrectly
column8: something the experienced hikers were unlikely to have done.A similar theory alleges the testing of radiological weapons and is partly based on the discovery of radioactivity on some of the clothing as well as the bodies being described by relatives as having orange skin and grey hair. However
column9: radioactive dispersal would have affected all of the hikers and equipment instead of just some of it
column10: and the skin and hair discoloration can be explained by a natural process of mummification after three months of exposure to the cold and winds. Furthermore
column11: the initial suppression of files regarding the group's disappearance by Soviet authorities is sometimes mentioned as evidence of a cover-up
column12: but the concealment of information regarding domestic incidents was standard procedure in the USSR and therefore far from peculiar. And by the late 1980s
column13: all Dyatlov files had been released in some manner.

column1: International Science Times posited that the hikers' deaths were caused by hypothermia
column2: which can induce a behavior known as paradoxical undressing in which hypothermic subjects remove their clothes in response to perceived feelings of burning warmth. It is undisputed that six of the nine hikers died of hypothermia. However
column3: others in the group appear to have acquired additional clothing (from those who had already died)
column4: which suggests that they were of a sound enough mind to try to add layers.

column1: There were wide discrepancies in distances quoted between the two possible locations of the snow shelter where Dubinina
column2: Kolevatov

One location was approximately 80 to 100 meters from the pine tree where the bodies of Doroshenko and Krivonischenko were found and the other suggested location was so close to the tree that anyone in the snow shelter could have spoken to those at the tree without raising their voices to be heard. This second location also has a rock in the stream where Dubinina's body was found and is the more likely location of the two. However
column5: the second suggested location of the two has a topography that is closer to the photos taken at the time of the search in 1959.

column1: The location of the tent near the ridge was found to be too close to the spur of the ridge for any significant build-up of snow to cause an avalanche. Furthermore
column2: the prevailing wind blowing over the ridge had the effect of blowing snow away from the edge of the ridge on the side where the tent was. This further reduced any build-up of snow to cause an avalanche. This aspect of the lack of snow on the top and near the top of the ridge was pointed out by Sergey Sogrin in 2010.McCloskey also noted:
